awd_titl_txt: Emerging Mathematics and Computer Science Scholars (EMACS)
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at Saint Leo University in Saint Leo, Florida will award scholarships to low-income, academically talented students pursing bachelors degrees in computer science or mathematics. In addition to scholarships, the program will provide additional support in the form of faculty mentoring, interdisciplinary projects with faculty, tutoring and academic support,  along with networking and internship opportunities with industry. A key element of Saint Leo University's S-STEM program will be the formation of two interacting cohorts of mathematics and computer science students.  This cohort experience will be an  opportunity for students in both majors to engage effectively in exchanges of ideas, and to appreciate the interdisciplinary nature of the two fields.  At stronger familiarity with the complementary disciplines of mathematics and computer science is expected to help broaden the students' career perspectives to include emerging high-demand interdisciplinary career areas such as cybersecurity and data analytics. Scholarships and support for low-income and academically talented students, who may not otherwise be able to obtain STEM degrees, will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the nation's economic growth and competitiveness.

The S-STEM program will increase retention and degree completion for students majoring in mathematics or computer sciences, increase students' appreciation and understanding of the benefits each discipline offers the other, and help these students to develop the qualifications and interests needed to pursue the expanding career opportunities at the interface of applied mathematics and computer science. The project will create interacting cohorts of computer science and mathematics majors. Cohorts will take classes together, receive faculty mentoring from both disciplines, and participate in interdisciplinary group projects.  Students majoring in the fields of computer science and mathematics will learn their chosen field of study but, through an interdisciplinary approach, will develop experience in the other discipline.  It is expected that scholarship students in the program will show an increased appreciation for the power of integrating these disciplines and awareness of the extensive opportunities in interdisciplinary career options. The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the STEM education community.

por.por_cntn:
(1) The EMACS project demonstrated use of effective student supports and resources to improve retention in STEM through the creation of a cohort of living-learning community of S-STEM students supported by individualized peer and faculty mentoring; cohort-building social activities; group class scheduling; enhanced academic support such as a dedicated student success coach and peer mentoring; early alert and academic intervention; service learning and undergraduate research opportunities.

(2) The EMACS project increased student interest and persistence in STEM through a variety of cohort activities such as: STEM-focused team activities, use of an immersive hands-on robotics boot camp during the cohort orientation, cohort attendance and participation in STEM-focused technical conferences, cohort participation in STEM competitions, engaging cohorts in STEM-related outreach activities with local K-12 schools, cohort participation in summer research project experiences, organized field trips to research facilities, participation in faculty-mentored undergraduate research.

(3) The project enhanced student preparation for STEM careers and graduate school through cohort participation in the following activities: featured speaker presentations by industry leaders, panel discussions by invited speakers and business leaders on STEM careers, cohort participation in-person and virtual career fairs, focused career preparation workshops on resume writing, interview skills, and career planning, completion of internships by EMACS cohort participants, information sessions and individualized counseling sessions organized for the cohorts on graduate school admission process and graduate student experience.

(4) During the grant period, a total of 37 students from three different cohorts were supported by the EMACS program through scholarships and academic support and cohort building activities. At the end of the grant period, a total of 22 program participants have successfully graduated with their STEM degrees, and eleven others making good progress towards towards completing their respective degrees and are on track to graduate within one year. Among the 22 students in the program that have graduated, 13 have secured professional employment in STEM fields within six months of graduating, and 9 others have been admitted to graduate STEM degrees.

(5) The project was effective in supporting students' academic success. Across the project years, numerous students made the Dean's List. These high GPAs resulted in higher average GPAs among EMACS Scholars than other STEM students. Comparison of average GPAs for EMACS students to their non-EMACS peers demonstrates that project participants earned higher cumulative GPAs in both Math and Computer Science. Retention among project participants was consitently higher than the university average. All continuing EMACS students either graduated or persisted in their respective STEM majors till end of grant period.

(6) Strategies were put in place, tested, and shown to support higher retention rates of EMACS students than the SLU average, with 89% of students retained or graduated overall. Only 4 of 37 students, and all from the first 2 cohorts, had to leave the program due to poor academic performance or shift from STEM and each of these was replaced quickly. Experiences in the first 2 program years resulted in changes that supported 100% of Scholar retention in subsequent years.

(7) A robotics boot camp specifically designed for the incoming EMACS cohorts provides us a model to run similar STEM-focused bootcamps for current and propective students, as a vehicle to attract more students to STEM degrees.

(8) The EMACS program tested and refined an effective process to track EMACS students' academic progress (grades, persistence, retention, graduation). This data, together with other instruments such as student and mentor feedback surveys, enabled us to identify those elements of the program that contribute to student success, retention, and graduation in STEM fields.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Vyas Krishnan
